- Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 420 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts law on modification of child custody and the best interests of the child, citing Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 420 Mass. 1 (1995). The opinion text provided, however, is a criminal case involving G. L. c. 272, § 53 (lewd, wanton, and lascivious conduct), and addresses statutory construction, elements of the offense, and ex post facto concerns—not custody modification or best-interests standards. Thus, the supplied opinion text does not support the proposition for which the case is cited.
- Custody of a Minor (No. 2), 420 Mass..relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 272, § 53, provides criminal penalties for “lewd, wanton and lascivious persons in speech or behavior.” … We conclude that the Commonwealth’s evidence left an essential element of the offense to speculation. As a consequence, the defendant was entitled to an acquittal under his rule 25 (a) motion.

- Biller v. Biller, 434 Mass. 108 (2001).raw_text: - Biller v. Biller, 434 Mass. 108 (2001) (parental conduct and effect on custody determinations);

- Biller v. Biller, 434 Mass. 108 (2001).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is Western Massachusetts Lifecare Corp. v. Assessors of Springfield, a Massachusetts tax case about charitable property tax exemption and overvaluation, not Biller v. Biller. It does not concern custody modification, parental conduct, or the best interests of the child standard. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the family-law proposition for which it is cited.
- Biller v. Biller, 434 Mass. 108 (2001).relevant_excerpt: Western contends that, based on the agreed facts, it is entitled to an exemption from taxation on the property at Reeds Landing and that the board therefore erred as a matter of law in denying that exemption. Real estate owned by a “charitable organization” and occupied by another charitable organization “for the purposes of such other charitable organization” is exempt from taxation under G. L. c. 59, § 5, Third.

- Putnam v. Putnam, 437 Mass. 279 (2002).raw_text: - Putnam v. Putnam, 437 Mass. 279 (2002) (modification and child’s welfare);
- Putnam v. Putnam, 437 Mass. 279 (2002).proposition: Petitioner relies on Massachusetts statutes and relevant caselaw concerning modification of custody and the best interests of the child standard, including, without limitation, the following authorities:
- Putnam v. Putnam, 437 Mass. 279 (2002).support_reasoning: The cited opinion is a criminal case about discovery sanctions, interlocutory appeals, and double jeopardy arising from a heroin distribution prosecution. It does not involve domestic relations, custody, modification of custody orders, or application of the best-interests-of-the-child standard. Citing this case for Massachusetts law on modification of custody and a child’s welfare is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion’s subject matter or holdings.
- Putnam v. Putnam, 437 Mass. 279 (2002).relevant_excerpt: The defendant was charged on a complaint in the Boston Municipal Court Department with distribution of a class A controlled substance (heroin) ... The order excluding the Commonwealth’s evidence pertaining to the school zone measurements and drug analysis was erroneous. The order is, in essence, an inappropriate sanction for the Commonwealth’s alleged failure to provide discovery to the defendant in keeping with the pretrial conference report.

The claimed proposition concerns Massachusetts statutes and caselaw on modification of custody and the best interests of the child, which are entirely unrelated issues. Nothing in the excerpt (or in Driscoll v. Driscoll generally) addresses custody modification standards or best interests analysis, so the case does not support the proposition for which it is cited.

- Santos v. Santos, 430 Mass. 774 (2000).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about inventory searches of impounded vehicles, sufficiency of evidence, ineffective assistance of counsel, and prosecutorial misconduct. It does not address modification of child custody, material change of circumstances, or the best interests of the child standard, nor does it cite or apply any Massachusetts custody-modification statutes. Therefore it does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
- Santos v. Santos, 430 Mass. 774 (2000).relevant_excerpt: Under both the Federal and Massachusetts Constitutions, *773analysis of the legitimacy of an inventory search of an impounded vehicle involves two related, but distinct, inquiries: (1) whether the impoundment of the vehicle leading to the search meets constitutional strictures, and (2) whether the conduct and scope of the search itself meet those strictures.8 See Commonwealth v. Garcia, 409 Mass. 675, 678, 680 (1991)... Our examination of the constitutionality of this search centers instead on the validity of the impoundment.

- McGlynn v. McGlynn, 66 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: - McGlynn v. McGlynn, 66 Mass. App. Ct. 197 (2006) (parenting time enforcement and make-up time principles);
- McGlynn v. McGlynn, 66 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Petitioner relies on Massachusetts statutes and relevant caselaw concerning modification of custody and the best interests of the child standard, including, without limitation, the following authorities:
- McGlynn v. McGlynn, 66 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This case has nothing to do with custody, parenting time, or the best interests of the child. McGlynn v. McGlynn concerns internal governance and property control disputes within a congregational church and the limits of civil court jurisdiction under the First Amendment. It therefore does not support a proposition about Massachusetts statutes or caselaw on modification of custody or best-interests analysis in family law.
- McGlynn v. McGlynn, 66 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In this case involving a dispute between two factions of a congregational church, we consider the plaintiffs’ appeal from the dismissal, on jurisdictional grounds, of their complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief… At issue is whether, and for what purpose, the civil courts may entertain the case, consistent with the free exercise and establishment clauses of the First Amendment of the United States Constitution.”

- Hinton v. Hinton, 432 Mass. 677 (2000).raw_text: - Hinton v. Hinton, 432 Mass. 677 (2000) (consideration of children’s emotional well-being and transition difficulties);
- Hinton v. Hinton, 432 Mass. 677 (2000).proposition: Petitioner relies on Massachusetts statutes and relevant caselaw concerning modification of custody and the best interests of the child standard, including, without limitation, the following authorities:
- Hinton v. Hinton, 432 Mass. 677 (2000).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Hinton v. Hinton concerns reformation of an unambiguous will to correct a drafting or inducement mistake. It does not discuss custody, modification of custody orders, or the best interests of the child standard, nor does it address children’s emotional well-being or transition difficulties. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition for which it is being cited.
- Hinton v. Hinton, 432 Mass. 677 (2000).relevant_excerpt: Section 12.1 of the Restatement states principles that would permit an unambiguous will to be reformed to conform the text of the will to the testator’s intent when clear and convincing evidence establishes “(1) that a mistake of fact or law, whether in expression or inducement, affected specific terms of the document; and (2) what the donor’s intention was.” As the Restatement points out, and cases demonstrate, there are instances where mistakes in a will, of the nature described above, caused by scrivener’s error, incorrect legal advice, misrepresentations, and the like, may call for reformation of an unambiguous text.

- Hopkins v. Hopkins, 446 Mass. 420 (200.case_name: Mark Bombara Interior Design v. Bowler
- Hopkins v. Hopkins, 446 Mass. 420 (200.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts statutes and caselaw on modification of custody and the best interests of the child. Hopkins v. Hopkins, 446 Mass. 420 (2006), as quoted here, is a contract and home improvement/consumer protection case dealing with breach of contract, G.L. c. 142A, and G.L. c. 93A. It does not address child custody, modification standards, or the best interests of the child, so it does not support the stated proposition.
- Hopkins v. Hopkins, 446 Mass. 420 (200.relevant_excerpt: Bowler argues that the judge erroneously concluded that because Bombara neither held himself out as a contractor nor was, as a matter of law, a contractor as defined in G. L. c. 142A, § 1, he was not liable under G. L. c. 142A, § 2, for failing to submit a prescribed contract, or under G. L. c. 142A, § 17, for failing to disclose that he was not a registered contractor or failing to complete the project without excuse. We agree.
